docs.lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES what is important about a primary season is what doesn't happen. Exhibit A: The absence of a major Presidential candidate to speak, whole-heartedly and full-throatedly, for Republicans who support abortion rights or are otherwise uncomfortable with the conservative social agenda. Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania made an effort, quoting Barry Goldwater's libertarian credo of a Government kept "out of our pockets, off our backs and out of our bedrooms." But Mr. Specter was gone by November, out of money and stalled in the polls in the low single digits. Steve Forbes has more middle-of-the-road positions on social issues than most of his colleagues, but he his emphasis has been on the flat tax.

headline.main: Right Hook;G.O.P.'s Libertarian Streak Becomes a Blur

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH the nation's tax rules in seemingly constant flux, even tax professionals are occasionally tripped up. Ask Nadine Gordon Lee, a partner with Ernst & Young, the Big Six accounting firm in New York. Ms. Lee, a mother of two boys, prepared the paperwork and paid the Federal unemployment tax for her baby sitter in January, when she received the forms in the mail from the Internal Revenue Service. She had grown accustomed to the quarterly blizzard of paperwork needed to pay Social Security and unemployment taxes for baby sitters and other domestic employees.

headline.main: In Confusion Over Tax Law, Don't Overlook Some Changes

docs.lead_paragraph: BLAME it on Barney, the ubiquitous purple dinosaur, or blame it on nostalgia for the psychedelic '70's. But these days, more and more new cars are painted purple. Buyers like the attention they get from purple. "I get thumbs up when I drive through the streets," said Renee I. Pepper, a psychotherapist in Chappaqua, N.Y., who drives a deep, metallic purple Chevrolet Blazer she bought last February. "Every gas attendant always comments on it."

headline.main: Now, the Color Purple Has Wheels

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, pupils at the Joseph Kushner Hebrew Academy have yearned for more space. Their gymnasium also serves as a cafeteria and auditorium, and their synagogue has been the setting for banquets and plays. But this fall, the 400 children in pre-kindergarten through eighth grade will abandon the squat metal building for an enormous new school in nearby Livingston with a pillared facade, courtyards, playing fields, a swimming pool and a synagogue. The move, which will cost the private Jewish day school about $10 million, will also enable it to open the first Orthodox Jewish high school in Essex County, one of a handful around the state. Right now, Essex County residents who want to attend Orthodox high schools must commute to Paramus, Elizabeth or New York City, said Susan Dworken, the principal.

headline.main: One School's Expansion Mirrors a Growing Interest in Jewish Education

docs.lead_paragraph: Bergen Pines County Hospital started 80 years ago as a sanitarium in the truck-farm country of Paramus for people with contagious diseases. Over the years, it grew into a giant health center for the poor, the elderly and those with acute psychiatric problems. Today it is the state's largest hospital, and the seventh-largest public hospital in the nation. But soon the hospital may be in private hands. Even though it has turned a profit in recent years and is no longer a multimillion-dollar drain on Bergen County's taxpayers, county officials say it is too unwieldy to continue under public management and must be sold or merged to survive in the rapidly changing world of health care.

headline.main: Huge and Unwieldy, a County Hospital Talks of Privatizing

docs.lead_paragraph: When President Clinton delivered his State of the Union Message last month, no part was more warmly applauded than his declaration that the "era of big government is over." To the audience and the President, "big government" meant the huge Federal bureaucracy, with its thousands of programs and workers. But even as the number of Federal workers has begun to shrink significantly for the first time in decades, there has been enormous growth in a largely unnoticed side of the ledger: Federal liabilities.

headline.main: GOVERNMENT CUTS MAY CAUSE LOSSES IN LOAN PROGRAMS

docs.lead_paragraph: Announcing the most sweeping military changes since development of a nuclear deterrent almost 40 years ago, President Jacques Chirac said tonight that France's armed forces would shrink by about a third and become an all-volunteer force within six years. To replace the military draft for young men, a hallowed institution since Napoleon, Mr. Chirac called for a national debate about how both men and women could serve France in civilian jobs instead.

headline.main: Cold War Over, France Plans a Slim, Volunteer Military

docs.lead_paragraph: Business and labor leaders in New Jersey began a joint lobbying effort today against a legislative proposal that would use $1.1 billion from the state's unemployment insurance fund over the next four years to help pay for hospital care for the poor. The state's authority to divert revenues from the Unemployment Compensation Fund expired on Dec. 31. State legislative leaders, who rejected Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposal last fall to raise cigarette taxes, proposed last week to continue drawing on the unemployment fund, but to reduce reliance over the next four years until total spending for charity care is included in the state's operating budget by the year 2000.

docs.lead_paragraph: In this small town surrounded by corn fields, nothing but Sunday morning church bells ever made much noise, and the jail sat three-quarters empty most of the time. And then about a year or so ago, things started to go haywire.

headline.main: Good People Go Bad in Iowa, And a Drug Is Being Blamed
